questions.question: A taxpayer should itemize deductions when:

options.B: Total itemized deductions exceed the standard deduction

questions.explanation: Taxpayers should itemize when their total itemized deductions exceed the standard deduction. After TCJA nearly doubled the standard deduction, fewer taxpayers benefit from itemizing. The decision is purely mathematical—choose the larger deduction.
questions.tip: Itemize only if total itemized > standard deduction. Do the math.

questions.question: The 2023 standard deduction for married filing jointly is:
questions.explanation: For 2023, the standard deduction is $27,700 for married filing jointly, $13,850 for single and married filing separately, and $20,800 for head of household. These amounts are indexed annually for inflation.
questions.tip: 2023 standard deduction: $27,700 MFJ, $20,800 HoH, $13,850 single/MFS.

questions.question: Medical expenses are deductible to the extent they exceed:

options.B: 7.5% of AGI

questions.explanation: Medical and dental expenses are deductible as itemized deductions to the extent they exceed 7.5% of AGI. This threshold was made permanent at 7.5% after fluctuating between 7.5% and 10% in prior years.
questions.tip: Medical deduction = expenses exceeding 7.5% of AGI.

questions.question: Home mortgage interest is deductible on acquisition debt up to:

options.B: $750,000 for loans originated after December 15, 2017

questions.explanation: For mortgages originated after December 15, 2017, interest is deductible on acquisition debt up to $750,000 ($375,000 MFS). Loans originated before that date are grandfathered at the $1,000,000 limit. Home equity loan interest is only deductible if used to buy, build, or improve the home.
questions.tip: Mortgage interest: $750K limit for post-12/15/2017 loans; $1M grandfathered.

questions.question: The state and local tax (SALT) deduction is limited to:

options.B: $10,000 ($5,000 if married filing separately)

questions.explanation: TCJA imposed a $10,000 cap ($5,000 MFS) on the combined deduction for state and local income taxes (or sales taxes) and property taxes. This limit applies through 2025 and significantly impacts taxpayers in high-tax states.
questions.tip: SALT cap: $10,000 total ($5,000 MFS) for state/local income + property taxes.

questions.question: Cash contributions to public charities are generally deductible up to:

options.B: 50% of AGI

questions.explanation: Cash contributions to public charities (50% organizations) are deductible up to 60% of AGI under TCJA through 2025 (increased from 50%). Contributions of appreciated property are limited to 30% of AGI. Lower limits apply to private foundations.
questions.tip: Charitable cash: 60% AGI limit (through 2025). Appreciated property: 30% AGI limit.

questions.question: Which of the following is a deductible medical expense?

options.B: Health club membership for general fitness

questions.explanation: Prescription medications and insulin are deductible medical expenses. Cosmetic surgery (unless for disfigurement from disease, accident, or congenital abnormality), gym memberships for general health, and non-prescription vitamins are not deductible.
questions.tip: Deductible medical: prescriptions, doctor visits, hospital. NOT gym, cosmetics, vitamins.

questions.question: When contributing long-term capital gain property to a public charity, the deduction is generally:

options.B: Fair market value, limited to 30% of AGI
options.C: Fair market value, limited to 50% of AGI

questions.explanation: Long-term capital gain property contributed to a public charity is deductible at fair market value (no gain recognition), but the deduction is limited to 30% of AGI. The taxpayer can elect to use basis and get the 50% limit instead.
questions.tip: LTCG property to charity: FMV deduction at 30% limit, or elect basis at 50% limit.

questions.question: Investment interest expense is deductible to the extent of:

options.B: Net investment income

questions.explanation: Investment interest expense (interest on loans to purchase taxable investments) is deductible as an itemized deduction only to the extent of net investment income. Excess interest carries forward indefinitely to future years.
questions.tip: Investment interest limited to net investment income. Excess carries forward.

questions.question: Under current law, personal casualty losses are deductible only if:

options.B: They result from a federally declared disaster

questions.explanation: TCJA limits personal casualty loss deductions to losses from federally declared disasters only (2018-2025). The loss must exceed $500 per casualty (increased from $100 by TCJA under IRC §165(h)(5)) and total losses must exceed 10% of AGI. Casualty gains can offset non-disaster losses.
questions.tip: Personal casualty loss: federal disaster only (TCJA). Still need $500 + 10% AGI floors.

questions.question: Gambling losses are deductible:

options.B: Only to the extent of gambling winnings
options.D: Only if the taxpayer is a professional gambler

questions.explanation: Gambling losses are deductible as an itemized deduction, but only to the extent of gambling winnings reported as income. Gambling winnings must be reported in full; losses cannot create a net deduction.
questions.tip: Gambling losses limited to winnings. Report all winnings, deduct losses up to that amount.

questions.question: For a cash charitable contribution of $300, the taxpayer must have:

options.B: A bank record or written receipt from the charity

questions.explanation: All cash contributions, regardless of amount, require a bank record (canceled check, credit card statement) or written communication from the charity showing the amount and date. Contributions of $250 or more require a contemporaneous written acknowledgment.
questions.tip: Cash charity: bank record or receipt for any amount. $250+ needs written acknowledgment.

questions.conceptTested: Donation of clothing and household items
questions.question: Donated clothing and household items are deductible only if:

options.B: They are in good used condition or better
options.C: The taxpayer has owned them for more than one year
options.D: They are donated to a public charity

questions.explanation: Donated clothing and household items must be in good used condition or better to be deductible. A deduction may be allowed for items not in good condition if the deduction exceeds $500 and a qualified appraisal is obtained.
questions.tip: Donated clothes/household items: must be in good condition (or get appraisal if >$500).

questions.question: The standard mileage rate for charitable purposes is:

options.B: 22 cents per mile

questions.explanation: The charitable mileage rate is set by statute at 14 cents per mile and does not change with inflation. This is significantly lower than the business mileage rate (65.5 cents for 2023) or medical/moving rate (22 cents for 2023).
questions.tip: Charity mileage = 14 cents (fixed by statute). Much lower than business rate.

questions.question: Points paid on the purchase of a principal residence are:

options.B: Deductible in the year paid if certain requirements are met
options.C: Always amortized over the loan term
options.D: Deductible only if paid by the seller

questions.explanation: Points paid on the purchase of a principal residence are generally fully deductible in the year paid if: (1) the loan is secured by the principal residence, (2) points are computed as a percentage of the loan, (3) charging points is an established practice in the area, and (4) points don't exceed typical amounts.
questions.tip: Points on home purchase = deduct in year paid (if typical and meets requirements).

questions.question: Points paid on refinancing a home mortgage are:

options.A: Fully deductible in the year paid
options.B: Amortized over the life of the new loan
options.D: Deductible only if the loan increases

questions.explanation: Points paid on a refinanced mortgage must be amortized over the life of the loan. However, if the refinance is on the principal residence and part of the proceeds are used for home improvements, that portion of points may be currently deductible.
questions.tip: Refinance points = amortize over loan life. Purchase points = deduct immediately.

questions.question: Under the SALT deduction, taxpayers may deduct:

options.A: Both state income taxes and state sales taxes
options.B: State income taxes OR state sales taxes, but not both

questions.explanation: Taxpayers may deduct either state and local income taxes or state and local sales taxes, but not both. Those in states without income tax (like Texas or Florida) often benefit from deducting sales taxes. Either choice is combined with property taxes for the $10,000 SALT cap.
questions.tip: SALT: choose income tax OR sales tax (not both), plus property tax. Total capped at $10K.

questions.question: Excess charitable contributions that exceed the AGI limitation may be:

options.B: Carried forward for 5 years

questions.explanation: Charitable contributions exceeding the applicable AGI percentage limitation (60%, 50%, 30%, or 20%) may be carried forward for 5 years. Carryovers are used after current year contributions and retain their original character.
questions.tip: Excess charitable contributions: 5-year carryforward. Used after current year gifts.

questions.question: Medical expenses paid by credit card are deductible:

options.A: When the credit card bill is paid
options.B: In the year the charge is made
options.C: Over the period the payments are made
options.D: Only in the year the medical service is received

questions.explanation: Medical expenses paid by credit card are deductible in the year the charge is made, not when the credit card bill is paid. The credit card company pays the provider, creating an obligation to the credit card company, which is considered payment.
questions.tip: Credit card medical expenses: deduct when charged, not when card is paid off.

questions.question: Real property taxes are deductible by:

options.A: Only the person whose name is on the deed
options.B: The person who pays them, even if not the owner
options.C: The owner of the property who pays them
options.D: Only if the property is a principal residence

questions.explanation: Real property taxes are deductible by the owner who pays them. A tenant paying property taxes on behalf of a landlord cannot deduct them. If property is sold mid-year, taxes are prorated between buyer and seller based on ownership period.
questions.tip: Property taxes: owner who pays can deduct. Prorate on sale.

questions.question: For a donated vehicle worth more than $500, the charitable deduction is generally:

options.B: Limited to the gross proceeds from the charity's sale of the vehicle
options.C: The taxpayer's basis in the vehicle

questions.explanation: For donated vehicles worth more than $500, the deduction is generally limited to the gross proceeds from the charity's sale. Exceptions allow FMV if the charity materially improves the vehicle or uses it substantially for charitable purposes.
questions.tip: Vehicle donation >$500: deduction = what charity sells it for (unless they use/improve it).

questions.question: Cash contributions to private non-operating foundations are limited to:

options.B: 50% of AGI

questions.explanation: Cash contributions to private non-operating foundations are limited to 30% of AGI (vs. 60% for public charities). Contributions of appreciated property to private foundations are generally limited to 20% of AGI and deductible at basis, not FMV.
questions.tip: Private foundation limits: cash = 30% AGI; appreciated property = 20% AGI at basis.

questions.question: When a donor receives goods or services in exchange for a contribution, the deduction is:

options.B: The amount paid minus the fair market value of goods/services received
options.C: Zero, because it is not a true contribution
options.D: The fair market value of goods/services received

questions.explanation: For quid pro quo contributions (where donor receives something in return), only the excess of the payment over the FMV of goods or services received is deductible. Charities must provide written disclosure for payments over $75.
questions.tip: Quid pro quo: deduct payment minus value received. Charity must disclose if >$75.

questions.question: When contributing ordinary income property to charity, the deduction is limited to:

options.B: The taxpayer's basis in the property

questions.explanation: Contributions of ordinary income property (inventory, short-term capital gain property, Section 1245 recapture property) are deductible at the donor's basis, not FMV. This prevents donors from avoiding ordinary income recognition by donating appreciated ordinary income property.
questions.tip: Ordinary income property donation = basis only (not FMV). No end-run around ordinary income.

questions.question: A taxpayer donating appreciated capital gain property may elect to:

options.A: Increase the AGI limitation by paying additional tax
options.B: Deduct basis instead of FMV to use the higher cash contribution AGI limit (60%) instead of 30%
options.D: Treat the property as ordinary income property

questions.explanation: Donors of appreciated capital gain property can elect to deduct basis (rather than FMV) to qualify for the higher AGI limitation that applies to cash contributions (60% through 2025) instead of the 30% limit for FMV of appreciated property. Electing basis treatment allows use of the cash contribution AGI limits. This may benefit taxpayers with large donations relative to AGI.
questions.tip: Appreciated property election: use basis for higher AGI limit. Good if high donation relative to income.

questions.question: A qualified appraisal is required for noncash charitable contributions exceeding:
questions.explanation: A qualified appraisal by a qualified appraiser is required for noncash contributions exceeding $5,000 (per item or group of similar items). Form 8283 Section B must be completed, and the appraiser must sign it.
questions.tip: Noncash >$5,000 = qualified appraisal required. Form 8283 Section B.

questions.question: Qualified conservation contributions of appreciated property are deductible up to:

options.B: 50% of AGI with 15-year carryforward
options.D: 100% of AGI for farmers and ranchers

questions.explanation: Qualified conservation contributions are deductible up to 50% of AGI (100% for qualified farmers and ranchers), with excess carried forward for 15 years instead of the normal 5 years. These are perpetual restrictions on property use for conservation purposes.
questions.tip: Conservation easements: 50% AGI limit (100% for farmers), 15-year carryforward.

questions.question: Medical expenses paid for a dependent are deductible if:

options.A: The person was a dependent when the expense was incurred OR paid
options.B: The person is currently claimed as a dependent
options.C: The taxpayer provides more than half the person's support
options.D: The person lived with the taxpayer all year

questions.explanation: Medical expenses are deductible if paid for someone who was a dependent either when the medical services were provided or when the expenses were paid. The dependent must meet the relationship and support tests but not necessarily the gross income test.
questions.tip: Medical for dependent: qualify when services provided OR when paid. Flexible timing.

questions.question: Long-term care insurance premiums are deductible as medical expenses:

options.B: Up to age-based limits as a medical expense
options.C: Only if the taxpayer is in a nursing home

questions.explanation: Qualified long-term care insurance premiums are deductible as a medical expense up to age-based dollar limits (ranging from $480 for ages 40 and under to $5,960 for ages 71+ in 2023). The premiums are then subject to the 7.5% AGI floor.
questions.tip: LTC insurance premiums: deductible up to age-based limits, then subject to 7.5% floor.

questions.question: Under TCJA, miscellaneous itemized deductions subject to the 2% floor are:

options.B: Suspended and not deductible from 2018-2025

questions.explanation: TCJA suspended miscellaneous itemized deductions subject to the 2% floor from 2018-2025. This includes unreimbursed employee expenses, tax preparation fees, investment expenses, and safe deposit box rental for investment purposes.
questions.tip: 2% floor deductions: GONE through 2025 (employee expenses, tax prep, etc.).

questions.question: Foreign real property taxes are:

options.B: Not deductible under TCJA (2018-2025)

questions.explanation: TCJA eliminated the deduction for foreign real property taxes on personal residences from 2018-2025. However, foreign taxes on investment or rental property remain deductible as business expenses. Foreign income taxes may still be deducted or credited.
questions.tip: Foreign property taxes on personal residence: not deductible (TCJA). Rental property OK.

questions.question: The 'bunching' strategy for itemized deductions involves:

options.B: Accelerating or deferring deductions to exceed the standard deduction in alternate years
options.C: Claiming both standard and itemized deductions
options.D: Converting itemized deductions to FOR AGI deductions

questions.explanation: Bunching involves timing discretionary deductions (charitable contributions, property taxes, medical procedures) to concentrate them in alternate years, allowing itemization in some years while taking the standard deduction in others. This maximizes total deductions over time.
questions.tip: Bunching: concentrate deductions in one year to itemize, take standard in off years.

questions.question: Contributions to a donor-advised fund are:

options.A: Not deductible until grants are made to charities
options.B: Deductible when made to the fund, subject to public charity limits

questions.explanation: Contributions to donor-advised funds are deductible when made (not when grants are distributed), subject to public charity AGI limits (60% cash, 30% appreciated property). The donor gives up ownership but can recommend grants. DAFs are useful for bunching deductions.
questions.tip: DAF contribution: deductible when made (public charity rules). Great for bunching strategy.

questions.question: A qualified charitable distribution (QCD) from an IRA:

options.A: Is included in income and then deducted
options.B: Is excluded from income and cannot be claimed as a charitable deduction
options.C: Is only available to taxpayers under age 70½
options.D: Can be made to donor-advised funds

questions.explanation: QCDs allow taxpayers age 70½ or older to distribute up to $100,000 directly from an IRA to charity. The distribution is excluded from income (no deduction taken). QCDs can satisfy RMDs and benefit those who don't itemize.
questions.tip: QCD: excluded from income, satisfies RMD, no deduction. Age 70½+, up to $100K/year.

questions.question: The Pease limitation on itemized deductions under current law is:

options.A: Still in effect for high-income taxpayers
options.B: Suspended from 2018-2025 under TCJA
options.D: Set at 3% of AGI over threshold amounts

questions.explanation: The Pease limitation (which reduced itemized deductions by 3% of AGI over threshold amounts, up to 80% of certain deductions) was suspended by TCJA from 2018-2025. Currently, itemized deductions are not phased out based on income.
questions.tip: Pease limitation: SUSPENDED through 2025. No AGI phase-out of itemized deductions.
